doc: Single or multi line argument providing the list of SMARTS that identify the atoms to be included in the analysis.

Specifies the value of the cutoff (default: 0.6 Ã…). Being rA and rB the v.d.w radii of two atoms A and B, and d the interatomic distance, an atom clash occurs if the overlap=(rA + rB - d - allowance) between atoms A and B is larger than a specific cutoff. The allowance is a value in angstrom that allows to specify that some atoms can came closer to each other that the sum of their van der Waals radii. If the given string is parsable to a double, then it is used as the value. Otherwise, the string is interpreted as an expression defining the value (e.g., '${sin(0.2)}' would be evaluated to the value of the sine of 0.2).

specifies the value of the allowance (default: 0.4). See CUTOFF. If the given string is parsable to a double, then it is used as the value. Otherwise, the string is interpreted as an expression defining the value (e.g., '${sin(0.2)}' would be evaluated to the value of the sine of 0.2).

Specifies the value of the allowance between atoms in 1-3 relationship. See CUTOFF. If the given string is parsable to a double, then it is used as the value. Otherwise, the string is interpreted as an expression defining the value (e.g., '${sin(0.2)}' would be evaluated to the value of the sine of 0.2).

Specifies the value of the allowance between atoms in 1-4 relationship. See CUTOFF. If the given string is parsable to a double, then it is used as the value. Otherwise, the string is interpreted as an expression defining the value (e.g., '${sin(0.2)}' would be evaluated to the value of the sine of 0.2).

Specifies the value of the allowance between specific pairs of atoms that defined by SMARTS strings. Custom allowances can be defined by single or multi line argument (one custom allowance per line) according to the following syntax: <String> <String> <String>, where the strings are SMARTS queries and the third string is the pair-specific allowance (which can be either a double value or an expression). If the given string is parsable to a double, then it is used as the value. Otherwise, the string is interpreted as an expression defining the value (e.g., '${sin(0.2)}' would be evaluated to the value of the sine of 0.2). See CUTOFF.

tag: the importing of chemical objects (e.g., molecular geometries)
